revision.text:
[[File:Palace of prince Alexander of Bulgaria (engraving).jpg|thumbnail|300px|right|The palace of Knyaz Alexander, where he was taken prisoner by the conspirators of the 1886 coup]]
The '''Bulgarian coup d'état of 1886''', also known as the '''9 August coup d'état''' ({{lang-bg|Деветоавгустовски преврат}}, ''Devetoavgustovski prevrat'') was an attempted dethronement of Knyaz [[Alexander of Battenberg|Alexander Battenberg]] in [[Principality of Bulgaria]], carried out on 9 August 1886. Although unsuccessful, the event led to the [[abdication]] of Alexander Battenberg.<ref>{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Bulgaria/History}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=Frank Marby|author2=Amos Shartle Hershey|title=Handbook for the Diplomatic History of Europe, Asia, and Africa 1870-1914|publisher=National Board for Historical Service, Government Printing Office|location=Washington, DC|date=1918|chapter=The Bulgarian Revolution of 1885 |chapterurl= https://archive.org/stream/handbookfordiplo00ande#page/118/mode/2up |pages= 119–122}}</ref>
==Background== After the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–78)]] Bulgaria was [[Liberation of Bulgaria|liberated from Ottoman rule]] and Knyaz Alexander Battenberg was elected in 1879 as Prince of Bulgaria at the request of the Russian Tsar, his uncle, [[Alexander II of Russia|Alexander II]]. The latter was assassinated in 1881 and was succeeded by the conservative [[Alexander III of Russia|Alexander III]].
The relations between Bulgaria and [[Russian Empire|Russia]] suffered after the [[Bulgarian unification]] with [[Eastern Rumelia]] in 1885, which had not been approved by Russia. Prior to the subsequent [[Serbo-Bulgarian War]], Russia had withdrawn its military officers, who had commanded all larger units of Bulgaria's young army until that point.
Despite the successful Unification of Bulgaria, the Rusophile circles in the country held Knyaz Alexander Battenberg responsible for the deterioration of relations with Russia. The Rusophiles had valued Russia's role in supporting the restoration of Bulgaria as a state in the boundaries, promised by the preliminary [[Treaty of San Stefano]].
==Coup== On the eve of 8 to 9 August 1886 Alexander Battenberg was arrested in his palace in [[Sofia]], forced to sign a decree for his abdication, and expelled from Bulgaria to Russia by boat. A provisional government was installed, led by [[Kliment of Tarnovo]]. However, the coup was not backed by many Bulgarian officers and politicians, including the chief of the National Assembly, [[Stefan Stambolov]]. A conter-coup, led by [[Sava Mutkurov]], was organized in [[Plovdiv]] and the members of the original coup were quickly isolated. On 17 August 1886, Alexander Battenberg returned to Bulgaria, but his reign lasted only till 26 August 1886, when he abdicated of his own recognizance in an attempt to calm down the crisis in relations with Russia.
==Aftermath== The relations between Bulgaria and Russia continued to be hostile in the years following the coup. Bulgaria elected a new Knyaz on 7 July 1887, [[Ferdinand I of Bulgaria|Ferdinand I]] of the [[House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]], an Austrian Emperor's nephew and an officer in the Austrian army. Bulgaria's domestic political life was dominated during the early years of Ferdinand's reign by liberal party leader Stefan Stambolov, whose foreign policy saw a marked cooling in relations with Russia, formerly seen as Bulgaria's protector.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bulgarian coup d'etat of 1886}} [[Category:Military coups in Bulgaria]] [[Category:1886 in Bulgaria]] [[Category:August 1886 events]] [[Category:1880s coups d'état and coup attempts]]
{{Bulgaria-hist-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox road |country=CYP |type=A |route=3 |alternate_name=Larnaca International Airport – Ayia Napa
Αυτοκινητόδρομος Διεθνούς Αερολιμένα Λάρνακας - Αγίας Νάπας |map=A3 Motorway Cyprus map.png |map_notes=A3 highway diagram |length_km= 55 |beltway_city= [[Larnaca]] |terminus_a= [[Larnaca International Airport]] junction |junction= [[Image:B4 road cyprus.png|30px|B4 main road logo]] [[Larnaca International Airport]] Junction to Larnaca Center and [[Kiti, Cyprus|Kiti]] via [[B4 road (Cyprus)|B4]] [[Image:B5 road cyprus.png|30px|B5 main road logo]][[Image:A5 Motorway Cyprus.png|30px|A5 main road logo]][[Image:A1 Cyprus.png|30px|A1 highway logo]] [[Kalo Chorio, Larnaca|Kalo Chorio]] Junction to [[Larnaca]] center via [[B5 road (Cyprus)|B5]], [[Limassol]] via [[A5 motorway (Cyprus)|A5]]([[A1 motorway (Cyprus)|A1]]) [[Image:A2 Motorway Cyprus.png|30px|A2 highway logo]][[Image:A1 Cyprus.png|30px|A1 highway logo]] [[Rizoelia Junction]] to [[Larnaca]] city via [[A2 motorway (Cyprus)|A2]] and to Nicosia via [[A2 motorway (Cyprus)|A2]]([[A1 motorway (Cyprus)|A1]]) |terminus_b= [[Ayia Napa]] Main Roundabout |regions= [[Larnaca District]], [[Famagusta District]] |cities= |previous_type=A |previous_route=2 |next_type=A |next_route=4 }} The '''A3 motorway''' (''Greek: δρόμος Διεθνούς Αερολιμένα Λάρνακας - Αγίας Νάπας'') is a modern [[motorway]] linking [[Larnaca International Airport]], the largest airport in [[Cyprus]], and [[Ayia Napa]], a popular seaside destination. It is 55 km long. The road was built in five phases and took about 10 years to be completed. The first part of the road until [[Dhekelia Cantonment|Dhekelia]] is locally referred as "Larnaca [[Beltway]]" (''Greek: Παρακαμπτήριος Λάρνακας'') and the second part till the end of the motorway as "Dhekelia - Famagusta Motorway" (''Greek: Αυτοκινητόδρομος Δεκέλειας - Αμμοχώστου''). Its routing takes it past [[Aradippou]], [[Oroklini]], [[Xylotymvou]], [[Ormidia]], and [[Xylofagou]]. The Larnaca beltway section, until the final phase was completed, used to culminate in an acute bend which was a major accident blackspot. The motorway was built in 3 stages: 1. Rizoelia Junction to [[Dhekelia Cantonment|Dhekelia]] - opened 1993 2. Rizoelia junction to [[Dromolaxia]] - Opened 1999 3. [[Dhekelia Cantonment|Dhekelia]] to [[Ayia Napa]] - opened 2003 The western terminus was altered in 2009 to facilitate access directly to the new terminal at [[Larnaca International Airport]] [[Category:Motorways and roads in Cyprus]] [[Category:Limited-access roads]] {{Cyprus-transport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{Flagicon|France}} "Autant d'amoureux que d'étoiles" | image = | caption = | year = 1984 | country = France | artist = [[Annick Thoumazeau]] | as = | with = | language = French | languages = | composer = [[Vladimir Cosma]] | lyricist = Charles Level | conductor = François Rauber | place = 8th | points = 61 | lyrics = | prev = Vivre | prev_link = Vivre (Guy Bonnet song) | next = Femme dans ses rêves aussi | next_link = Femme dans ses rêves aussi }} '''"Autant d'amoureux que d'étoiles"''' ([[English Language|English]] translation: "As Many Lovers As Stars") was the [[France|French]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1984]], performed in [[French Language|French]] by [[Annick Thoumazeau]].
The song was performed third on the night (following [[Luxembourg]]'s [[Sophie Carle]] with "[[100% d'amour]]" and preceding [[Spain]]'s [[Bravo (band)|Bravo]] with "[[Lady, Lady]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 61 points, placing 8th in a field of 19.
The song is a dramatic ballad, with Thoumazeau promising her unending devotion to her lover and remarking that they are not the only lovers in the world - there in fact being ''"as many lovers as stars in the sky"''.
It was succeeded as [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest|French representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1985|1985 Contest]] by [[Roger Bens]] with "[[Femme dans ses rêves aussi]]".
==Sources and external links== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=300 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year, 1984] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1984fra Detailed info & lyrics, The Diggiloo Thrush, "Autant d'amoureux que d'étoiles".]
{{France in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1984}}

{{cite check|date=December 2017}} {{Excessive citations|date=December 2017}} The people who currently identify themselves as '''Basimba''' <ref>{{citation |title= Harmsworth History of the World: Man and the universe. Japan. Siberia. China| publisher= Carmelite House |year=1907| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=cdBLAQAAMAAJ|pp=322,325}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Tanganyika Notes and Records: Issues 38-50| publisher= Tanganyika Society |year=1955| url= https://books.google.co.ug/books?id=rKsaAQAAMAAJ|pp=167}}</ref> or <ref>{{citation |title= The Luapula Peoples of Northern Rhodesia:Customs and History in Tribal Politics | publisher= Manchester University Press |year=1959 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=eXi7AAAAIAAJ|pp= 63–64}}</ref> '''BaShimba''' for many and '''Musimba''' <ref>{{citation |title= A Gazetteer of Ethnology| publisher= Maruzen-Kabushiki-Kaisha|year=1908| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ndtfAAAAIAAJ|pp=55, 56}}</ref> or '''MuShimba''' for singular are [[Bantu languages|Bantu speaking]], [[Community]] that exist in [[Uganda]]{{Citation needed|reason=Previous citation did not support/prove this claim|date=December 2017}}. Before the 13th Century they did maintain a shared identity as Basimba also defined in [[Swahili Language]], as (a big lion),<ref>{{citation |title= Proceedings-Indian History Congress| publisher=Indian History Congress |year=1970| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=cglDAAAAYAAJ|pp=58}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Modern Swahili Grammar | publisher= East African Educational Publisher Ltd |year=2001| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=9966467610|pp=42}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Philosophy, oral tradition and Africanistics: a survey of the ... | publisher= P. Lang|year=1994| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=8tffAAAAMAAJ|pp=129, 137}}</ref> associated with either these people or the place which they came from.
The name Basimba or BaShimba (also known as the big Lion)<ref>{{citation |title= Allegorical Speculation in an Oral Society: The Tabwa Narrative ...| publisher= University of California Press | year=1989| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0520097394|pp=20}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Peoples of the Lake Nyasa Region - Parts 1-3 | publisher= International African Institute |year=1950| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=o9CAAAAAMAAJ|pp=80}}</ref> was applied to the whole group by the early [[Ovambo people]]<ref>{{citation |title= Journal of African zoology, Volume 92| publisher= M.P. Basilewsky |year=1978| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=9tRWAAAAMAAJ |pp=646}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Proceedings of the Royal Geographical Society and Monthly Record of Geography, Volume 8| publisher= Edward Stanford |year=1886| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=I1gMAAAAIAAJ |pp=650}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Proceedings of the Royal Geographical Society and Monthly Record of Geography, Volume 8| publisher= Edward Stanford |year=1886| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=PDIRAQAAIAAJ|pp=650}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Lantern, Volume 37| publisher= Adult Education Division, Union Education Department |year=1988| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=04UuAQAAIAAJ |pp=60}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Proceedings of the Royal Geographical Society and Monthly Record of Geography, Volume 8| publisher= Edward Stanford |year=1886| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=I1gMAAAAIAAJ|pp=650}}</ref> as a nickname for the leopard totem Clan people also known as bena Ngo in Zambia<ref>{{citation |title= The tribes of Zambia| publisher= the University of California| year=2011| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=PCBSAQAAIAAJ|pp=38}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Peoples of Zambia| publisher= Heinemann Educational | year=1978| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Wtl8AAAAMAAJ|pp=68,86}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Tribes of Northern Rhodesia | publisher= Government Printer, South Africa |year=1956| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=fKYwAAAAIAAJ|pp=31}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The tribes of Zambia| publisher= University of California |year=1978| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=PCBSAQAAIAAJ |pp=38}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Peoples of Zambia| publisher= Heinemann Educational |year=1978| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Wtl8AAAAMAAJ|pp=68}}</ref> and in Uganda as abe Ngo.<ref>{{citation |title=Conflict in Africa: Concepts and Realities | publisher= Princeton University Press| year=2015| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1400867428|pp=173}}</ref>
The founder of [[Buganda]], [[Kato Kintu]] <ref>{{citation |title= Chronology, migration, and drought in interlacustrine Africa | publisher= Africana Pub. Co |year=1978| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=IkNyAAAAMAAJ|pp=150}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Myth, Ritual, and Kingship in Buganda | publisher= Oxford University Press |year=1991| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4pZyAAAAMAAJ|pp=95}}</ref> in the 14th Century was the first [[Kabaka of Buganda|Kabaka]] of the [[Kingdom of Buganda]] the father of [[Chwa I of Buganda]] in his [[immigration]]<ref>{{citation |title=History of Buganda: From the Foundation of the Kingdom To 1900| publisher=Africana Publishing Company|year=1972| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YLIqAAAAYAAJ|pp=35, 94, 95}}</ref> to Buganda (by then known as Muwaawa), went with thirteen clans known as (Abalasangeye) under the Kintu dynasty,<ref>{{citation |title= Expanding frontiers of African history: the inter-disciplinary ... | publisher= University of Calabar Press| year=1988| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZXIyAAAAIAAJ|pp=153}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Bitter Bread of Exile: The Financial Problems of Sir Edward Mutesa II| publisher= Progressive Publishing House |year=2013| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=9970464000|pp=6}}</ref> and among these thirteen Clans was the Basimba Leopard (Ngo) Clan.<ref>{{citation |title= Beyond the Royal Gaze: Clanship and Public Healing in Buganda | publisher=University of Virginia Press |year=2010 | url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0813929709 |pp=36,37,38,39}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Africa from the Twelfth to the Sixteenth Century | publisher= James Currey |year=1959 | url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0852550944 |pp= 208}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Kingship and State: The Buganda Dynasty|publisher= Cambridge University Press|year=2002| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0521894352|pp=102, 117, 118, 173, 187, 211, 213}}</ref> King [[Kateregga of Buganda]],<ref>{{citation |title= The Kings of Buganda | publisher= East African Publishing House |year=1971| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=hnkWAAAAIAAJ|pp=42}}</ref> between 1674-1680 C. at the current [[Butambala District]], persecuted the Leopard (Ngo) Clan people killing four hundred of its members and causing others to conceal their [[Cultural identity]]. Given the pre-eminent role of the Leopard (Ngo) Clan in the [[Cult]] of Kintu, these people expected that in the event they were discovered to be briefly related to the Leopard (Ngo) Clan would have far reaching consequences and the same happened during Kabaka [[Jjunju of Buganda]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}}.
==Royal Links== The Bashimba (Big Lion) of the Leopard totem Clan is a ruling Clan <ref>{{citation |title= Zambia Museums Journal - Volume 8| publisher= National Museums of Zambia |year=2003| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lIoMAQAAMAAJ|pp=80}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Ba Shiru - Volume 12, Issue 1 - Volume 13, Issue 1|publisher= University of California Press |year=1981| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=0hNAQAAMAAJ|pp=60}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=The New Diffusionist, Volume 2|publisher= New Diffusionist Press |year=1972| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=9d4WAQAAMAAJ|pp=7}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Azande: and related peoples of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and Belgian Congo, Issues 7-9| publisher= International African Institute |year=1953| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sTKBAAAAMAAJ|pp=65}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Ethnographic survey of Africa; East Central Africa, Parts 9-13 |publisher= Published for the International African institute by the Oxford university press |year=1953| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sTKBAAAAMAAJ|pp=65,137,138}}</ref> among the Royal Clans <ref>{{citation |title= Changing Roles: The History of the Development and Disintegration of Nkuba's Shila State to 1740|publisher= University of Wisconsin |year=1976| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BKlfAAAAMAAJ|pp=27,28}}</ref> that moved from the Kingdom of Luba to Luapula Valley in Northern Rhodesia.
The leopard (Ngo) totem Clan is a Kingship group among the Basimba (Big Lion) people <ref>{{citation |title= Twenty Five Years in East Africa| publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1921| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sdg5AAAAIAAJ|pp=167}}</ref> which was persecuted so much in Buganda because of its royal links.<ref>{{citation |title= Chronology, migration, and drought in interlacustrine Africa | publisher= Africana Pub. Co | year=1979| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0841903778|pp=150}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Twenty-five Years in East Africa | publisher= Cambridge University Press| year=1985| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sdg5AAAAIAAJ|pp=167}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Handbook of Uganda| publisher= government of the Uganda Protectorate |year=1913| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=uxkUAAAAIAAJ|pp=90}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Handbook of Uganda| publisher= government of the Uganda Protectorate |year=1920| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=CxoUAAAAIAAJ|pp=129}}</ref> Among the many Leopard Clan branches, one of it was eligible for the throne. Reigning kings of Buganda would always capture this group and execute most of its men to reduce the risk of being overthrown.[[Clans]] give a sense of shared identity and descent to members.
After the death of Kabaka [[Nakibinge of Buganda]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalark.net/Uganda/buganda2.htm|title=The History And Life of Kabaka Nakibinge|date=|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=Royalark.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buganda.com/kings.htm|title=Ssekabaka Nakibinge Is Buried At Kongojje, Busiro|date=| accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=Buganda.com}}</ref> his wife Nannono of the Leopard (Ngo) Clan between 1554 and 1556 AD, presided over as Kabaka for eighteen (18) month and the name Nabulya which literally means ‘I ate it’ insinuating I once took royal power was introduced in the Leopard (Ngo)Clan to remind other Clans in Buganda that a woman from the Leopard totem Clan once had power in Buganda Kingdom.
==Migration and Settlement== Although little history has been known about the Basimba (Big Lion) people, more needs to be said because of their very close historical connection with the BaShimba <ref>{{citation |title= Mutomboko Ceremony and the Lunda-Kazembe Dynasty| publisher= Kenneth Kaunda Foundation |year=1989| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=7XIyAAAAIAAJ|pp=89,95,103}}</ref> who all belong to the Leopard (Ngo) Clan. Most Basimba people claim their origin lies in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], among the [[Luba people]] of the [[Kingdom of Luba]]. Little is actually known about these immigrants, but traces of their history are found in the legend of the Tabwa<ref>{{citation |title= Zambia Museums Journal - Volume 8| publisher= National Museums of Zambia |year=2003| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lIoMAQAAMAAJ|pp=1}}</ref> ancestor.
Kyomba the ancestor of the Tabwa, a legendary man existed and lived on the Eastern shores of [[Lake Tanganyika]]. Faced with [[Hamitic]] pressures in the North and the people from the South to South, Kyomba and his companions crossed Lake Tanganyika by migrating to the Western shores of the Lake. Then Kyomba and his companions emigrated after the conspiracy mounted and hatched against him to the West and reached the shores of [[Lake Kivu]]. Then they crossed the Ruzizi and arrived Maniema and on the banks of river Lualaba to the second half of the 16th Century. Fanger son of Kyomba and his companions continued their migration up the river while others went elsewhere. The name Tumanya means “those that have followed the route by water’’ and Bena Kilunga means “those who followed the path on land in their migration”. The Bena Kilunga group migrated to the eastern banks of the [[Lualaba River]] and [[Lukunga River]], together with Buanza, Mumba and the Basimba people.<ref>{{citation |title= A history of the Bemba: political growth and change in north-eastern Zambia before 1900| publisher= University of Wisconsin Press | year=1973| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=DR0OAQAAMAAJ|pp=152, 401, 410}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Tabwa: The Rising of a New Moon, a Century of Tabwa Art| publisher= University of Michigan Museum of Art | year=1985| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=n55PAAAAMAAJ|pp=88}}</ref>
The Tumanya group migrated to Ankori or the [[Nkole people]] <ref>{{citation |title= African Concord, Issues 72-96| publisher= Concord Press of Nigeria| year=1986| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZRJBAQAAIAAJ|pp=20}}</ref> and eastwards following the Luvua (Lualaba) while their companions Lualaba River to back the lagoons in [[Upemba Depression]]. It was around the 17th Century when the gradual arrival of people in the mountains from the plains of Lualaba Kamalondo and named these "Kundelungu" Mountains.<ref>{{citation |title=The Meteorology and Climate of Tropical Africa| publisher= Springer| year=2008| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=3540426361 |pp=402}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Gift: Economy, Society, and Environment in Central Africa| publisher= University of Wisconsin Press| year=2006| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ythyAAAAMAAJ|pp=12}}</ref> Finally, Tanga and his father Kyomba further migrated across the Luapula at the current location of the position of Kasenga and settled in southern Tanganyika where they were joined by members of Zimba Clan. <ref>{{citation |title= Tabwa: The Rising of a New Moon, a Century of Tabwa Art | publisher= University of Michigan Museum of Art, |year=1985| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=n55PAAAAMAAJ|pp=9}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Memory: Luba art and the making of history | publisher= Museum for African Art |year=1996| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=379131677X |pp=230}}</ref> , avoiding quarrels will Movwe who migrated to the [[Marungu highlands]].
The Basimba or BaShimba immigrants seem to have come in [[ethnic group]]s under the leadership of Mambwe, Mauwe,<ref>{{citation |title= Customary Law of the Haya Tribe, Tanganyika Territory | publisher= Negro University Press |year=1945| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=083714597X|pp=307,348,349,350}}</ref> Katunku, Ngulya, Mwati, Kaabya, Ntembe, Namuyonjo, Kabolesa, Kitembwa and Kooli among others. When these people reached Luapula Valley the current [[Luapula Province]] in Zambia, Mwanza Region, Northern Tanzania and at Butambala in Uganda, they decided to settle and the leader became the family or the Clan head. As the Basimba or BaShimba settlement grew the original leader, after several [[generation]], became to his descendants as [[mythical]].
Basimba or BaShimba people are recognized to be [[indigenous peoples]],<ref>{{citation |title= Ethnographic survey of Africa; East Central Africa, Parts 9-13|publisher= Oxford university press |year=1953| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=gtaAAAAAMAAJ|pp=137}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Ethnographic Survey of Africa, Volume 2, Issue 13| publisher= International African Institute |year=1962| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=IYZRAQAAIAAJ|pp=137}}</ref> because they were the first comers among the immigrants in Zambia or [[Northern Rhodesia]] by then and in Tanzania,<ref>{{cite journal |title= Tanzania Notes and Records |year=1956 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=xxIOAQAAMAAJ |pp= 54}}</ref> According to local tradition the original inhabitants were a Clan called the Basimba who lived in the area of Busere on [[Ukara Island]], in the South-East corner of [[Lake Victoria]], but it is not known what language they spoke and there are none of their descendants surviving. [[Tradition]] makes no mention of fighting between the Basimba immigrants and the people whom they found in Uhaya in Tanzania and at Butambala in Uganda. The Bashimba of the (Leopard clan) successfully resisted Nkuba <ref>{{citation |title= Ethnographic Survey of Africa: East Central Africa, Parts 1-4| publisher= International African Institute |year=1950| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=djgKAQAAMAAJ|pp=80}}</ref> in Northern Rhodesia (Zambia).
==Original homeland== The original homeland of the Basimba <ref>{{citation |title= man past and present|publisher= Cambridge University Press|year=1989| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_i89AAAAIAAJ|pp=250}}</ref> or BaShimba <ref>{{citation |title= Allegorical Speculation in an Oral Society: The Tabwa Narrative ..., Volume 122| publisher= University of California Press |year=1989| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0520097394|pp=20}}</ref> people or their ancestry is shrouded in myths and legends. Whereas they seem to have lost contact with their original ancestors in Congo among the [[Luba people]],leading to a cluster of Basimba (Big Lion) people migrate Northwards from Mweru – Luapula to [[Mwanza Region]] eventually erecting [[Human settlement]]'s among the [[Haya people]] in Tanzania, then at [[Butambala District]] in the central region of Uganda, [[Buddu]] <ref>{{citation |title= The historical tradition of Busoga, Mukama and Kintu| publisher= Clarendon Press|year=1972| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=hdZyAAAAMAAJ|pp=86,87,88,93,95}}</ref> in [[Masaka District]], Ntakaiwolu in [[Busoga]], Mpogo in [[Sironko District]], [[Butaleja District]] and at Lupada, Naboa,<ref>{{citation |title= A History of African Motherhood: The Case of Uganda, 700-1900| publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2013| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1107030803|pp=163}}</ref> [[Budaka District]], among the [[Gwere people]], in the Eastern parts of Uganda. Other Bashimba people settled in Northern Rhodesia (Zambia) which was part of [[Zimbabwe]].
==Culture== The Basimba practice the [[culture]] of performing [[ritual]]s and [[Ceremony|ceremonies]] of the Chishimba spirit similar to the,<ref>{{citation |title= Questioning Misfortune: The Pragmatics of Uncertainty in Eastern Uganda| publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1997| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0521595584|pp=128}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Book of Life, Knowledge and Confidence| publisher=Pacific Press |year=2012 | url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1471734633 |pp=112}}</ref> [[Loa]] or kongo loa culture practiced by the Basimba people of Haiti who were sold in [[slavery in Haiti]] from [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]].
The Basimba (Big Lion) people in Uganda maintain the Basimba Spiritual stone, this stone represents the Chishimba spirit and is related to the institution of kingship. Its absence constitutes the absence of political power. According to [[Traditional African religions]], the Chishimba spirit is synonymous to kingship and similar to the Kintu cult practiced by the leopard (Ngo) Clan people in [[Buganda]]. The Chishimba is kept in a specially prepared basket called ichipe ca calo—the basket of the nation or land. It is wrapped with bark cloth and kept in a specifically prepared shrine (ing'anda yaba Ba Chishimba or esawo lye ejjembe lya Basimba) dedicated to the spirit.<ref>{{citation |title=A Colonial Lexicon: Of Birth Ritual, Medicalization, and Mobility in the Congo | publisher= Duke University Press |year=1999| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0822323664|pp=288,314,410,463}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= African Study Monographs, Volumes 24-25| publisher= Research Committee for African Area Studies |year=2003| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wtAQAAIAAJ |pp=61}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= African Arts, Volume 36| publisher= African Studies Center, University of California, Los Angeles |year=2003| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_TvrAAAAMAAJ|pp=36}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Emblems of Passage: Art of Africa, Oceania, and the Americas : Selections from Friends of Ethnic Art Members' Collections | publisher= Museum of Craft & Folk Art |year=2002| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_TvrAAAAMAAJ|pp=40}}</ref>
Basimba people worked with [[Bunyoro]]-Kitara Kingdom's Priest in charge of the sacred pool of Muntebere. Each year the Bunyoro King sent a young slave-woman, two cows and a white sheep to the Priest. The slave-woman was given as a wife to one of the Abasimba Clan who was a servant of the Priest.
==The Abasimba Dance==
The abasimba dance of the Basimba people is a hunting dance performed by the Wajita or [[Jita people]] of [[Ukerewe Island]].<ref>{{citation |title= World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theater: Africa| publisher=Routledge |year=2013| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1136359494|pp=300}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Mashindano!: Competitive Music Performance in East Africa| publisher= Mkuki na Nyota Publishers, |year=2000| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=uh2fAAAAMAAJ|pp=180}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Continuum Companion to Twentieth Century Theatre| publisher= A & C Black |year=2006| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1847140017|pp=746}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Publication, Issue 20| publisher= The Institute |year=1981| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=JLhJAAAAYAAJ|pp=118}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Mutomboko Ceremony and the Lunda-Kazembe Dynasty| publisher= Kenneth Kaunda Foundation |year=1989| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=7XIyAAAAIAAJ|pp=96,97}}</ref>
The [[Basimba people Clan names]] of Uganda, Tanzania and Zambia are named after their lineal ancestors.
==Beliefs== Nowadays, between 40% to 50% of the Basimba people are [[Christians]]<ref>{{citation |title= Annual Report of the American Bible Society | publisher= American Bible Society | year=1971| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LiZXAAAAYAAJ|pp=58}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Zaire Church News-Volumes 1-60 | publisher= Congo Protestant Council | year=1912| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BrATAAAAIAAJ|pp=60}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Baptist Quarterly: Incorporating the Transactions of the Baptist Historical Society, Issues 1-8| publisher=Baptists| year=1972| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=dmYmAQAAIAAJ|pp=60}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Church, Clan and the World| publisher= Gleerup | year=1974| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=SsEOAQAAIAAJ|pp=22}}</ref> and 50% are [[Muslim]].<ref>{{citation |title= Women Writing Africa: The eastern region| publisher= Feminist Press at the City University of New York| year=2007| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1558615342|pp=255}}</ref> Besides that, traditional beliefs are very widespread among them. The most important features are ancestor-worship (the term is called inappropriate by some authors) and [[totemism]].
The Basimba of [[Kisangani]] who martyred Dr. Paul Carison of the Christ Church during the [[Congo Crisis]] of 1964 to 1965 participated in the [[Simba Rebellion]] that was later defeated.<ref>{{citation |title= Annual Report of the American Bible Society, Volume 156| publisher= American Bible Society |year=1971| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LiZXAAAAYAAJ|pp=58}}</ref>
==Ancestors== According to Basimba tradition, an [[afterlife]] does take place in another world, it is another form of existence in another world. The Basimba attitude towards dead ancestors is very similar to that towards living parents and grandparents. There is a famous ritual to contact the dead ancestors that is practiced by the Basimba people.<ref>{{citation |title= Questioning Misfortune: The Pragmatics of Uncertainty in Eastern Uganda| publisher= Cambridge University Press| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0521595584|pp=126}}</ref> It is similar to [[Haitian Vodou art]] related to [[Loa]] a [[Haitian vodou]] <ref>{{citation |title= Full Guide to Becoming a Real Wizard, Witch Or Necromancer| publisher= Lulu. com| year=2009| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1449967639|pp=62}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Doo Doo That Voodo| publisher= Pedia Press| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sfA26kAvkcYC|pp=1}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Mythologies| publisher= Pedia Press| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Y21XOYRQUgQC|pp=496}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Creole Religions of the Caribbean: An Introduction from Vodou and .| publisher= NYU Press| year=2003| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0814727204|pp=102}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Hegel, Haiti,: And Universal History | publisher= University of Pittsburgh Press | year=2009| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=i7EkAQAAMAAJ|pp=129}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Roots of Haiti's Vodou-Christian Faith: African and Catholic ...| publisher= ABC-CLIO | year=2014| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1440832048|pp=73}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Spirits and the Law: Vodou and Power in Haiti | publisher= University of Chicago Press | year=2011| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0226703800|pp=260}}</ref> religion practiced by the Basimba people of [[Haiti]] an Island that was proclaimed by [[Napoleon]] as an independent republic in 1804 and often lasts all night.
==Totems== Basimba totems (muziro) have been in use among the Basimba people since the initial development of their culture. Totems identify the different clans among the Basimba people that historically made up the dynasties of their ancient civilization. There are seven different totems that have been identified among the Basimba (Big Lion)people in [[Zimbabwe]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], [[Zambia]] and [[Uganda]] , such as the Basimba among the Haya Tribe in [[Tanzania]],.<ref>{{citation |title= Origins of Kingship, Traditions and Symbolism in the Great Lakes Region of Africa |publisher= Coronet Books Incorporated |year=2008 | url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=9155472958|pp= 89}}</ref> People of the same Clan use a common set of totems usually animals or birds.<ref>{{citation |title= Africa and the Wider World: East, central, and southern Africa since 1800| publisher=Longman Nigeria| year=1965| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_JgPAQAAMAAJ|pp=45,118}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= South African Journal of Science: Being the Organ of the South African Association for the Advancement of Science, Volumes 17-18| publisher=South African Association for the Advancement of Science| year=1920| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=2a8rAQAAMAAJ|pp=220}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Encyclopædia Britannica - Volume 22 | publisher= Encyclopædia britannica Company, Limited| year=1929| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=G5ezUHsW4ZAC|pp=300,316}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Encyclopædia Britannica: A New Survey of Universal Knowledge, Volume 22| publisher= Encyclopædia Britannica| year=1956| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=m287AAAAIAAJ|pp=318}}</ref>
Examples of animal totems include Ngo/mbwili ([[Leopard]]),<ref>{{citation |title= Totemism and Exogamy, Vol. II (in Four Volumes)| publisher= Cosmo, Inc.|year=2013| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1605209791|pp=624}}</ref> [[Leopard Cat]], Genet [[Cat]] which in the [[Lega language]] is known as Musimba<ref>{{citation |title= Lega Culture; Art, Initiation, and Moral Philosophy Among a Central African ...| publisher= University of California Press| year=1973| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0520020855|pp=146}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Africa-Tervuren, Volume 25 | publisher= Amis du Musée royal de l'Afrique centrale | year=1979| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=jesPAQAAMAAJ|pp=77}}</ref> and also known as Kasimba in luganda language and known as Zimba in the Luba language and Nshimba in the Bemba language, [[Lion]] (Mpologoma), Mbwa ([[Dog]]), Kikere ([[Frog]]) and Nkoko ([[Rooster]]). People of the same totem are the descendants of one common [[ancestor]] (the founder of that totem) and thus are not allowed to marry or have an intimate relationship. The totems cross regional groupings and therefore provide a wall for development of [[ethnic group]] among the Basimba.
Basimba chiefs are required to be able to recite the history of their totem group right from the initial founder before they can be sworn in as chiefs.
==Orphans== The totem system is a severe problem for many [[orphan]], especially for Basimba or BaShimba women<ref>{{citation |title= A Colonial Lexicon: Of Birth Ritual, Medicalization, and Mobility in the Congo| publisher= Duke University Press | year=1999| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0822323664|pp=288}}</ref> married to other Clans. The Basimba people are afraid of being punished by ghosts, if they violate rules connected with the unknown totem of a foundling. Therefore, it is very difficult to find adoptive parents for such children. And if the foundlings have grown up, they have problems getting married and on their death they are not buried on the Basimba ancestral grounds.
==Burials== The identification by totem has very important ramifications at traditional ceremonies such as the Basimba burial ceremony. A person with a different totem cannot initiate burial of the deceased. A person of the same totem, even when coming from a different tribe, can initiate burial of the deceased. For example, a Muganda of the Ngo (Leopard) totem can initiate burial of a Musimba of the Leopard totem and that is perfectly acceptable in Basimba tradition. But a Musimba of a different totem cannot perform the ritual functions required to initiate burial of the deceased.
If a person initiates the burial of a person of a different totem, he runs the risk of being asked to pay a fine to the family of the deceased. Such fines traditionally were paid with cattle or goats but nowadays substantial amounts of money can be asked for. If they bury their dead family members, they would come back at some point to cleanse the stone of the burial.
==Basimba Clan groups== The Basimba people consider themselves subjects of the Chishimba, the Basimba's single paramount Chief. These Basimba people lived in villages of 50 to 100 people and are now numbering to 100,000 in number by 2016. There are seven Basimba (Big Lion) people Clan groups named after animals<ref>{{citation |title= The Oxford Encyclopedia of African Thought: Abol-impe, Volume 1=| publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2010| url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0195334736|pp=382}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= The Native Races of Africa and Madagascar| publisher=the University of Michigan |year=1938| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sdg5AAAAIAAJ|pp=321}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Encyclopaedia of Religion and Ethics-Volume 2| publisher= Scribner |year=1957| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=63MrAQAAMAAJ|pp=352, 353}}</ref> and these are:- # The [[Leopard]], (Ngo) [[Clan]]. # The [[Leopard Cat]] Clan. # The Genet [[Cat]] (Kasimba) Clan. # The [[Lion]],(Mpologoma) Clan. # The [[Frog]] Clan. # The [[Dog]] Clan. # The [[Rooster]] Clan. Some of the Basimba people migrated northwards from Luapula valley after the disintegration of the Shila states and others remained in Northern Rhodesia currently known as BaShimba or abeena Ngo (Leopard) totem Clan. The BaShimba Leopard totem Clan is a ruling clan among the [[Lungu]] and [[Bemba people|Bemba]].
==Countries Basimba People Exist== Basimba or BaShimba<ref>{{citation |title= Works Issued by the Hakluyt Society| publisher= The Society|year=1901| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=wok7AAAAIAAJ|pp=207}}</ref> people exist in [[Zambia]] formerly known as Northern Rhodesia, [[Zimbabwe]], [[Uganda]], [[Haiti]],[[DR Congo]] and [[Tanzania]]. For example, the omugurusi of the Basimba clan is Mauwe who on the day of his birth a dog had puppies. This dog often washed Mauwe as a child by licking him. Mauwe later out of gratitude, ordered his descendants to consider the dog as their friend, the word "Basimba" or "BaShimba" actually has several meanings. It may designate people of Basimba people origin regardless of where they live e.g. whether they live in urban areas or in the original rural Basimba areas of Mpogo, [[Sironko]] , Lupada, Naboa in [[Budaka District]] or [[Butambala District]], Mooni,[[Mbale District]]<ref>{{citation |title= Keeping The Faith|publisher= Lulu.com| year=2017| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1365828646|pp=183}}</ref> in [[Uganda]], Luapula Valley in Zambia or Northern Rhodesia and [[Kagera Region]] among the [[Haya people|Haya]] tribe in Bugorora Ward or County of [[Missenyi District]] in [[Tanzania]]. The original language of the Basimba people is unknown.
The BaShimba people living in Zambia's [[Northern Province, Zambia|Northern province]], among the [[Lungu people|Lungu]] and [[Bemba people|Bemba]] tribes speak the language which is most closely related to the [[Bantu languages]] the [[Lungu language|Lungu]] and [[Bemba language|ChiBemba]] (in Zambia and the DRC), [[Haya language|Haya]] (in Tanzania) and [[Luganda]] of the Baganda and [[Lugwere]] of the [[Gwere people]] (in Uganda). In Uganda, Luganda is mainly spoken in the central and eastern parts of Uganda, and has become the most widely spoken language in the Country, although not always as a first language.
==Genealogy== The [[History]] or [[Genealogy]] of the Basimba (Big Lion) people has given rise to numerous debates among [[historians]] to whether the Basimba people of the Leopard (Ngo) Clan in Uganda come with [[Kabaka of Buganda|Kabaka]], [[Kato Kintu]]<ref>{{citation |title= People's Names: A Cross-cultural Reference Guide to the Proper Use ...| publisher= McFarland & Company |year=1997| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kAUWAQAAIAAJ|pp=305}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Dictionary of African Historical Biography| publisher=University of California Press |year=1989| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0520066111|pp=72, 109}}</ref> in the 14th Century or migrated either direct from Congo or Luapula valley to Uganda.<ref>{{citation |title= Tanganyika Notes and Records: Issues 13-20| publisher= Tanganyika Society |year=1942| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kaoaAQAAMAAJ|pp=3}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Tanganyika Notes and Records: Issues 13-18| publisher= Tanganyika Society |year=1942| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=xa8KAQAAIAAJ|pp=3}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= From Blessing to Violence: History and Ideology in the Circumcision Ritual ...| publisher=Cambridge University Press| year=1986| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0521314046|pp=42}}</ref>
Some historians, anthropologists and sociologists like [[David William Cohen]], Ian George Cunnison,Hans Cory, Mwelwa Chambika Musambachine, [[Gideon Were]],Stephen Kyeyune, Tausir Niane, Mary Douglas, M. Hartnoll, Dr. Schinz and Fisher A. B among others have written books about Basimba people but have not stated the names of the Basimba [[ancestors]] who left the [[Luba people]] in Congo and migrated to places like Zambia, Zimbabwe, [[Tanzania]] and [[Uganda]]. Some historians who have written [[History of Africa]] books, use imprecise narrative documents to make estimates which must be treated with caution. Societies like [[Anthropological Society of London]] and [[Ethnological Society of London]] have also not yet published a full physical or cultural aspects of the Basimba people or due to the pronunciation of the name Basimba as [[Vazimba]] who migrated from East Africa and settled in Madagascar.<ref>{{citation |title= Ancestors, Power and History in Madagascar| publisher= BRILL|year=1999| url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=9004112898|pp=330}}</ref> The Vazimba are kinsmen of the Ba-Simba.<ref>{{citation |title= The Earth and Its Inhabitants …: South and East Africa| publisher= University of California |year=1895| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=JGdGAQAAMAAJ|pp=447}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Man, Past and Present| publisher= University Press |year=1900| url= |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/africa-nba-will-broadcast-more-500-games-tv-broadband-mobile-next-season-through-2357200 |title=In Africa, NBA Will Broadcast More Than 500 Games On TV, Broadband And Mobile Next Season Through Econet Partnership |website=Ibtimes.com |date=2015-08-01 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite web|author=Mike Richman |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/mandela-instrumental-popularizing-basketball-africa/1812584.html |title=Mandela Instrumental in Popularizing Basketball in Africa |website=Voanews.com |date=2013-12-18 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite web|author=elibawa |url=http://punchng.com/africa-basketball-league-dunks-off-in-lagos/ |title=Africa Basketball League dunks off in Lagos | Punch Newspapers |website=Punchng.com |date=2016-03-05 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite web|author=Eben Novy-Williams |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-21/national-basketball-association-agrees-to-africa-tv-media-deal |title=National Basketball Association Seals Africa TV Deal |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2016-04-21 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/basketball/raptors-gm-brings-hope-to-a-continent-with-giants-ofafrica/article26336168/ |title=Raptors GM brings hope to a continent with Giants of Africa |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=2015-09-12 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/aug/01/nba-game-africa-basketball |title=NBA brings the stars to Africa – but can basketball compete with soccer? | Sport |website=[[The Guardian]] |date=2016-02-09 |accessdate=2016-07-18}} [[Hakeem Olajuwon]] is considered instrumental in developing and popularizing Basketball in Africa. == History == Introduced to Africa around the 1960s basketball has become a very popular sport. After more people took notice and practiced, professional teams were formed. The managers of the first African National Federation decide to participate and compete in FIBA, which is the world basketball governing body. {{Cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/africa/history|title=History|website=FIBA.com|access-date=2016-11-10}} Held on the 30th and 31st of August 1960 the FIBA Congress allowed the Egyptian Basketball Federation to set up an institution in order to compete. This led to the integration of twelve African countries to join FIBA and the world stage. These countries include Burkina Faso, Ethiopia, Egypt, Ghana, Guinea Conakry, Mali, Morocco, Libya, North Rhodesia, Sierra Leone, Sudan and Togo. Currently, FIBA Africa grew to a point where every single country in Africa has a designated team, leading to 54 active teams in the institution. The activities of the youth program [[Basketball Without Borders]] in Africa, and program director [[Masai Ujiri]], are profiled in [[Hubert Davis (filmmaker)|Hubert Davis]]'s 2016 documentary film ''[[Giants of Africa]]''.[https://www.thestar.com/sports/raptors/2016/09/02/masai-ujiri-building-on-hope-with-giants-of-africa-arthur.html "Masai Ujiri building on hope with Giants of Africa: Arthur"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', September 2, 2016. == Major Influences == === [[Hakeem Olajuwon]] === One of the greatest African-born player to ever play the game of basketball. Hakeem was born in Lagos, Nigeria and his skills were great enough to be picked up by American college teams.He would go on to be drafted by the Rockets and win 2 championships, 2 Finals MVPs, as well as having the pleasure of being conducted in two Hall of Fame's; one from the NBA and another from FIBA.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/2015/news/features/shaun_powell/07/30/hakeem-olajuwon-godfather-of-basketball-in-africa/ |title=Olajuwon: Godfather of basketball in Africa |website=NBA.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18}} Hakeem success has paved the way for many international players to try and compete in the NBA and also inspired many scouts to look for new talent in other places in the world besides the US.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/13/opinion/masai-ujiri-africa-basketball/index.html |title=Why Africans will be basketball stars of tomorrow - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2015/07/30/basketball-without-borders-africa-luol-deng-masai-ujiri-chris-paul-exhibition-game/30903465/ |title=NBA helping basketball grow in Africa with grassroots efforts |website=Usatoday.com |date=2015-08-01 |accessdate=2016-07-18}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Africa topic|Basketball in}} [[Category:Basketball in Africa| ]] {{Africa-stub}}

{{Infobox political party | name = Burundi Workers' Party | colorcode = Red | foundation = 1979 | ideology = [[Communism]]
[[Marxism-Leninism]] | country = Burundi }} '''Burundi Workers' Party''' or '''UBU''' ({{lang-fr|Parti des travailleurs du Burundi}}; {{lang-rn|Umugambwe wa'Bakozi Uburundi}}) was a clandestine [[communist party]] in [[Burundi]]. Its primary constituency was the large Burundian [[refugee]] population situated in neighboring [[Rwanda]]. Founded in August 1979, one of its most prominent leaders was the ethnic [[Hutu]] intellectual [[Melchior Ndadaye]], who became the first democratically elected [[president of Burundi]] in 1993. When UBU was disbanded, followers of Ndadaye regrouped into the [[Front for Democracy in Burundi]] (FRODÉBU). ==Sources== *Eggers, Ellen K. ''Historical dictionary of Burundi''. 2nd ed. [[Lanham, Maryland|Lanham]]: Scarecrow Press, 1997. ({{ISBN|0-8108-3261-5}}) [[Category:Defunct political parties in Burundi]] [[Category:Communism in Burundi]] [[Category:Communist parties in Africa]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1979]] [[Category:1979 establishments in Burundi]] [[Category:Political parties with year of disestablishment missing]] {{Africa-party-stub}} {{Burundi-stub}}

[[Philippine Airlines|PAL Holdings, Inc]] (49%) | company_slogan = | founded = 1997 (1st incarnation)
2013 (current) | commenced = | ceased = 2014 | headquarters = [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]] | key_people = [[Kith Meng]] (Chairman, The Royal Group)
[[Ramon S. Ang]] (CEO, PAL Holdings, Inc.) | hubs = [[Phnom Penh International Airport]] | secondary_hubs = | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = | lounge = | alliance = | website = [http://www.cambodiaairlines.com.kh www.cambodiaairlines.com.kh] }} {{Contains Khmer text}} [[File:Cambodia International Airlines Boeing 737-200 Volpati.jpg|thumb|A Cambodia Airlines Boeing 737-200.(1st incarnation)]] '''Cambodia Airlines''' was an [[airline]] in [[Cambodia]] owned by [[The Royal Group]][http://www.phnompenhpost.com/2013052965903/Business/cambodia-airlines-to-get-20m.html "Cambodia Airlines to get $20m"], ''Phnom Penh Post''{{dead link|date=October 2017}} and [[Philippine Airlines|PAL Holdings, Inc.]] of the [[Philippines]]. ==History== Cambodia Airlines was founded in 1997 but its operations ceased in 2005.[http://www.airlineupdate.com/content_public/airlines/se_asia/cambodia.htm World Airline Directory] In 2013, [[Philippines|Philippine's]] flag carrier [[Philippine Airlines]] formed a joint ventureDoris C. Dumlao and Paolo G. Montecillo (4 April 2013), [http://business.inquirer.net/115333/pal-kith-meng-of-cambodia-sign-deal-to-set-up-cambodia-airlines "PAL, Kith Meng of Cambodia sign deal to set up Cambodia Airlines"], Inquirer BusinessLawrence Agcaoili (4 April 2013), [http://www.philstar.com/business/2013/04/04/926595/pal-royal-group-cambodia-form-international-airline-venture "PAL, Royal Group of Cambodia form international airline venture"], ''The Philippine Star''Kim Arveen Patria (4 April 2013), [https://ph.news.yahoo.com/pal--cambodian-group-to-launch-new-international-airline-094834761.html "PAL, Cambodian group to launch new international airline"], Yahoo! News Philippines with The Royal Group of [[Cambodia]] by buying a 49% stake in Cambodia Airlines. San Miguel Corporation, a diversified conglomerate in the [[Philippines]] bought a stake in PAL Holdings, Inc. and took control of the management of [[Philippine Airlines]] from the [[Lucio Tan]] group. The Royal Group of [[Cambodia]] owned 100% Cambodia Airlines prior to the joint venture. Inter-country operations between [[Manila]] and [[Phnom Penh]] are expected to begin in June while international flights is set to start in October the same year. Both countries are currently served by [[Cebu Pacific]] with its [[Manila]]-[[Siem Reap]] route. In 2014, the airline went out of business.{{cite web|url=http://www.ch-aviation.com/portal/airline/KMH|title=Cambodia Airlines|publisher=ch-aviation|date=16 April 2016}} ==Fleet== The Cambodia Airlines would initially lease two [[Airbus A320]] for international flights and two [[Bombardier Dash 8]] for domestic.

{{lowercase}} '''danceWEB Europe''' is a non profit association of dance organisations based in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] led by "danceWEB/Vienna". Funded under the "Culture 2000 programme of the European Union"<ref>[http://europa.eu.int/comm/culture/eac/index_en.html Culture 2000 programme of the European Union] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509044342/http://www.europa.eu.int/comm/culture/eac/index_en.html |date=2006-05-09 }}</ref> in 2002 to 31 May 2005 with a community grant of €900.000,00<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/culture/eac/sources_info/pdf-word/organisateurs.pdf Culture 2000, 2002 approvals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070412230231/http://ec.europa.eu/culture/eac/sources_info/pdf-word/organisateurs.pdf |date=2007-04-12 }}</ref> and in 2005 up to 31 May 2008 with a community grant of € 900.000,00 .<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/culture/eac/culture2000/pdf/projets2005/PA_A2_2005.pdf Culture 2000, 2005 approvals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070716181528/http://ec.europa.eu/culture/eac/culture2000/pdf/projets2005/PA_A2_2005.pdf |date=2007-07-16 }}</ref> to develop [[contemporary dance]] throughout [[Europe]] and to link the international dance scene and education, enhancing dialogue between cultures.<ref>[http://www.dancewebeurope.net/index.php?id=19 About danceWEB Europe]</ref>
==Activities== *Scholarships: the scholarship program started in 1996 awarded to 50 dancers each year, the scholarships provide for participation in the [[ImPulsTanz Vienna International Dance Festival]]. *Multimedia: technology and the web are used as a tool to use the mass media. Short documentaries have been produced of contemporary dance performances to reach a broad audience. *Coproduction / Touring: emerging European choreographers and dancers are supported in multinational projects and touring.
==Members== {| class="wikitable" style="width: 50%" ! Country !! City !! The '''eclectic paradigm''' is a theory in economics and is also known as the '''OLI-Model or OLI-Framework''', standing for <u>O</u>wnership, <u>L</u>ocation and <u>I</u>nternalization.<ref name="hagen">{{cite book |title= Deutsche Direktinvestitionen in Grossbritannien, 1871-1918 |last= Hagen |first= Antje |year= 1997 |publisher= Franz Steiner Verlag |location= Jena |isbn= 3-515-07152-0 |page= 32 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BqjhLmKdj0AC&printsec=frontcover&hl=de#PPA32,M1 |format= Dissertation |language= German }}</ref><ref name="twomey">{{cite book |title= A Century of Foreign Investment in the Third World |last= Twomey|first= Michael J. |year= 2000 |publisher= Routledge |location= |isbn= 0-415-23360-7 |page= 8 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=2uZFPyqHMGcC&printsec=frontcover#PPA8,M1 |format= Book}}</ref> It is a further development of the [[internalization theory]] and published by [[John H. Dunning]] in 1979.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dunning|first1=John|title=Toward an Eclectic Theory of International Production: Some Empirical Tests|journal=Journal of International Business Studies|date=1979|volume=11|issue=1|pages=9–31|jstor=154142}}</ref>
* '''<big>O</big>wnership advantages'''<ref name="hagen" /><ref name="twomey" /> specific advantages refer to the competitive advantages of the enterprises seeking to engage in [[Foreign direct investment]] (FDI). The greater the competitive advantages of the investing firms, the more they are likely to engage in their foreign production.<ref name="Dunning">{{cite journal|url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=MiamiImageURL&_cid=271686&_user=1461291&_pii=S0969593199000359&_check=y&_origin=&_coverDate=30-Apr-2000&view=c&wchp=dGLzVlB-zSkWz&md5=2a4f0e2f2a22b2186075ec63a8b6dfd4/1-s2.0-S0969593199000359-main.pdf |title= The eclectic paradigm as an envelope for economic and business theories of MNEactivity |accessdate= 2011-10-12 |last= Dunning |first= John H. |date= 2000|doi=10.1016/S0969-5931(99)00035-9 |volume=9 |journal=International Business Review |pages=163–190}}</ref> * '''<big>L</big>ocation advantages''' <ref>Gray, H. Peter (2003). "Extending the Eclectic Paradigm in International Business: Essays in Honor of John Dunning"; Edward Elgar Publishing</ref><ref name="twomey" /> Locational attractions refer to the alternative countries or regions, for undertaking the value adding activities of multinational enterprises (MNEs). The more the immobile, natural or created resources, which firms need to use jointly with their own competitive advantages, favor a presence in a foreign location, the more firms will choose to augment or exploit their O specific advantages by engaging in FDI.<ref name="Dunning" /> * '''<big>I</big>nternalization advantages'''<ref name="twomey" /> Firms may organize the creation and exploitation of their core competencies. The greater the net benefits of internalizing cross-border intermediate product markets, the more likely a firm will prefer to engage in foreign production itself rather than license the right to do so.<ref name="Dunning" />
== Sources == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Eclectic Paradigm}} [[Category:International economics]]

{{Infobox_Diplomatic_Mission | name = Embassy of Ireland, Paris | image = Hotel de breteuil76.jpg | address = 12 Avenue Foch, Paris, 75116 | location = [[Paris]] | coordinates = {{coord|48.8740752|N|2.2914557|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | ambassador = [[Patricia O'Brien]] | website = [https://www.dfa.ie/irish-embassy/france/ Irish Embassy, Paris] }}
The '''Embassy of Ireland''' in [[Paris]] ({{lang-fr|Ambassade d'Irlande à Paris}}) is the [[diplomatic mission]] of [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] to [[France]]. It is located at 12 Avenue Foch in the [[16th arrondissement of Paris|16th arrondissement]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=30661 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009143417/http://web.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=30661 |archivedate=2014-10-09 |df= }}</ref>
The embassy is also represented in France by [[Consul (representative)|Honorary Consuls]] in [[Cherbourg-Octeville|Cherbourg]], [[Antibes]]/[[Cannes]] and [[Lyon]]. The embassy is accredited to [[Monaco]], where it also has an honorary consul.
The current Ambassador to France is [[Patricia O'Brien]], previously the Irish Ambassador to the [[United Nations]] and Other International Organisations, Geneva.
== Building == Built in 1892 by architect [[Ernest Sanson]], the embassy is located in the historic [[Hôtel de Breteuil]]. The building was sold to the [[Government of Ireland|Irish Government]] in 1954 when the lease on the former Embassy on Rue Paul-Valery expired.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfa.ie/irish-embassy/france/about-us/the-embassys-history/|title=The Embassy's History - Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|website=www.dfa.ie|language=en|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref>
In 2006, the reception rooms of the chancery underwent extensive renovations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=30660|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006120524/http://web.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=30660|archivedate=2014-10-06|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2014-09-27|df=}}</ref>
== See also ==

{{Infobox scientist | name = Erin Pettit | image = Pettit campus.jpg | birth_date = 1971 | nationality = United States | fields = [[Glaciology]]
[[Geophysics]] | workplaces = [[University of Alaska]] | alma_mater = [[University of Washington]] | awards = | website ={{url|http://www.explore-ice.gi.alaska.edu}} }} '''Erin Christine Pettit''' (born 1971) is an American [[Glaciology|glaciologist]] focusing on [[climate change]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.explore-ice.gi.alaska.edu/about/|title=About|website=ice|access-date=2016-05-17}} She is an associate professor of [[geophysics]] and glaciology at the [[University of Alaska Fairbanks]], [[Alaska]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/explorers/bios/erin-pettit/|title=Erin Pettit, Geophysicist and Glaciologist|last=|first=|website=NationalGeographic.com|access-date=2016-08-21}} Her work focuses on [[ice shelf]] disintegration, [[Sea level rise|sea-level rise]] and [[ocean circulation]] changes. == Early life and education == Pettit, born in 1971, is originally from [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]]. She started her academic career pursuing an Sc.B. in mechanical engineering at [[Brown University]], which she received in 1994.{{Cite web|url=http://glaciers.gi.alaska.edu/people/pettit|title=Erin Pettit|last=|first=|date=|website=Glaciers Group|publisher=[[University of Alaska Fairbanks]]|access-date=19 May 2016}} Before she attended graduate school, she lived in [[Los Angeles]] where she volunteered for the [[Sierra Club]].{{Cite news|url=http://polarfield.com/blog/girls-ice-mountaineering-adventure-learning-experience-young-women/|title=Girls on Ice: A Mountaineering Adventure and Learning Experience for Young Women|last=|first=|date=24 January 2013|work=Polar Field|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}} She then went on to earn her Ph.D. in [[Geophysics]] from the [[University of Washington]] (UW) in 2003, where her dissertation focused on the dynamic behavior of ice divides. Pettit also worked as a postdoctoral research fellow at UW until 2006 and then became a research physical scientist at the [[Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory|Cold Regions Research and Engineering Lab]] in New Hampshire. In 2008, she moved to The University of Alaska, Fairbanks ([[University of Alaska Fairbanks|UAF]]), and promoted to Associate Professor. == Career and impact == [[File:Rothera station 2.jpg|thumb|Pettit at [[Rothera station]]]] Pettit's research is primarily focused on glacial dynamics and exploring the interactions within the ice-ocean-earth system. Pettit is a [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] Emerging Explorer who innovated applying acoustic research with hydrophones to calving and melting glaciers reaching the ocean, to examine ice shelf disintegration and the ice-ocean boundary.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/explorers/bios/erin-pettit/.|title=Erin Pettit, Geophysicist and Glaciologist Information, Facts, News, Photos -- National Geographic|last=Society|first=National Geographic|access-date=2016-06-28}} Her work has been recognized by numerous high-profile sources, including ''[[American Geosciences Institute|EARTH magazine]],''{{Cite web|url=http://www.earthmagazine.org/article/down-earth-glaciologist-erin-pettit|title=Down to Earth With: Glaciologist Erin Pettit {{!}} EARTH Magazine|website=www.earthmagazine.org|access-date=2016-05-17}} and ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]],'' and she was invited to present a [[TED (conference)|TEDWomen talk]],{{Cite web|url=http://blog.ted.com/toward-new-more-nuanced-conversations-the-talks-in-session-5-of-tedwomen-2015/|title=Toward new, more nuanced conversations: The talks in Session 5 of TEDWomen 2015|date=2015-05-29|website=TED Blog|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-17}} on her investigations focused on "listening" to glaciers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/03/150306102608.htm|title=Melting Glaciers Create Noisiest Places in Ocean, Study Says|last=|first=|date=6 March 2015|work=[[Science Daily]]|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}} Her research on glacier sounds extends to how the underwater noise affects marine animals.{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/why-loud-noises-melting-glaciers-good-animals-180954508/|title=The Loud Noise of Melting Glaciers May Actually Be Good for Animals|last=Clark|first=Laura|date=9 March 2015|website=Smithsonian|publisher=|access-date=19 May 2016}} She also created and runs the Girls on Ice program, a wilderness science program that teaches high school girls about [[glaciology]], ecology, and mountaineering.{{Cite web|url=http://girlsonice.org/instructors/|title=Instructors|website=Girls on Ice|access-date=2016-05-22}} Girls on Ice started in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] in 1999, with Pettit taking five girls to the [[South Cascade Glacier]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.adn.com/science/article/girls-ice-program-alaska-washington-triggers-interest-science/2012/02/12/|title='Girls on Ice' Program in Alaska, Washington Triggers Interest in Science|last=Rozell|first=Ned|date=11 February 2012|work=Alaska Dispatch News|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}} During the program, adolescent girls learn [[mountaineering]] skills, how to use [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] for glacier measurement and how to calculate the velocity of streams.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/glaciologist-puts-her-girls-on-ice-133472775/?no-ist|title=Glaciologist Puts Her Girls on Ice|last=Bolen|first=Anne|date=October 2006|work=Smithsonian|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}} == Awards and honors == Pettit has received numerous awards including the National Science Foundation (NSF) Geoscience El Niño RAPID Award (2016),{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=137507|title=NSF Awards Rapid Response Grants to Study Current El Niño, One of the Strongest on Record|last=|first=|date=2 February 2016|website=National Science Foundation|publisher=|access-date=19 May 2016}} the Inspiring Women in STEM award, Insight into Diversity (2015),{{Cite web|url=http://www.insightintodiversity.com/100-inspiring-women-in-stem-awards/|title=100 Inspiring Women in STEM Awards|date=2015-08-18|website=INSIGHT Into Diversity|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-17}} the WINGS WorldQuest Earth Award (2007),{{Cite web|url=http://www.wingsworldquest.org/pettit/|title=Erin Pettit|website=WINGS WorldQuest|access-date=2016-05-17}} the David A. Johnston Memorial Scholarship Award (2000) as well as the UW Graduate School Merit Award (1997-1998). Petit received the UAF Teaching Award (2012) from the UAF College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics as well as a Merit Award for Research Excellence and Coordination for the Girls on Ice Program she initiated (2011). The Girls on Ice programme takes American teenage girls to Alaska and Washington State where they appreciate the climate and the experts who study it.[http://girlsonice.org/about/ About], Girls On Ice, Retrieved 21 August 2016 She became a National Geographic Emerging Explorer in 2013. She was appointed as a U.S. delegate to the international [[Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research]] in 2016 and as a representative for the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] Brazil-U.S. Women in Science Program (2011). Pettit received the National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship (1998-2003) and the Fannie and John Hertz Foundation Research Fellowship Grant (1997). == References == {{reflist|35em}} == External links == * [https://scholar.google.com.au/citations?user=DYLSOfAAAAAJ&hl=en Erin Pettit] on [[Google Scholar]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Pettit, Erin}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Glaciologists]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:University of Alaska Fairbanks faculty]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:21st-century American scientists]] [[Category:21st-century women scientists]] [[Category:Scientists from Seattle]] [[Category:American women geologists]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
{{Infobox fictional location | name = Genertela | colour = #C0C0C0 | image = Genertela.png | imagesize = 350px | caption = Map of Genertela by Christophe Dang Ngoc Chan | source = ''[[RuneQuest]]'', etc. | creator = [[Greg Stafford]] | genre = [[Role-playing game]] | type = continent | locations = Dragon Pass | people = }} '''Genertela''' is the northern [[continent]] of [[Greg Stafford]]'s [[fiction]]al world [[Glorantha]].
==Geography and climate== Genertela is divided into a few distinct regions by three great mountain ranges: * The Rockwood Mountains and their western extension, the Nidan Mountains, divide western and central Genertela into a northern and a southern half. * The Mislari and Skyreach Mountains separate the southwest from the central south and meet the Rockwoods in the Dragon Pass region of Maniria. * The Shanshan Mountains in the east separate the lands of Kralorela and Verenela from the steppes in eastern central Genertela.
The climate ranges from [[Arctic]] (Fronela and Valind's Glacier in the northwest) to [[subtropical]] (Verenela in the southeast).
==Inhabitants== The primary inhabitants are [[human]]s (of various racial types), as well as [[aldryami]] ([[elf|elves]]), mostali ([[dwarf (mythology)|dwarfs]]), uz ([[troll]]s) and less populous races such as durulz (large intelligent ducks with arms) and dragonewts.
==Regions== The major geographical regions, grouped by their predominant religious forms, are:
The West - ''[[Middle Ages|Medieval]] [[Monotheism]]'' * Fronela * Seshnela * Ralios
The Centre - ''[[Classical antiquity|Classical]] [[Polytheism]]'' * Peloria (inc. the Lunar Empire) * Maniria (inc. Dragon Pass)
The Wastelands - ''[[Nomad]]ic [[Shamanism]]'' * Prax * Pent
The East - ''[[The Orient|Oriental]] [[Mysticism]]'' * Kralorela * Verenela
[[Category:Fictional continents]] [[Category:Greg Stafford games]]

page.title: Group for a Switzerland Without an Army

revision.text:
The '''Group for a Switzerland without an Army''', (GSwA; {{lang-de|Gruppe für eine Schweiz ohne Armee}}, GSoA; {{lang-fr|Groupe pour une Suisse sans armée}}, GSsA; {{lang-it|Gruppo per una Svizzera senza Esercito}}, GSsE) is a group working to reduce the military activities of [[Switzerland]]. The Group was created in [[Solothurn]] on 12 September 1982 by 120 people.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110706233415/http://www.gssa.ch/spip/spip?article102 ]</ref> Its roster has varied considerably; as of 2009 its website states that it consists of about 20,000 members or supporters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gsoa.ch/english |title=English | GSoA - Gruppe für eine Schweiz ohne Armee |language=de |website=Gsoa.ch |date= |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref> consisting largely of [[pacifists]] and [[Anti-militarism|anti-militarists]].
==Means and objectives== The group is politically active and spreads awareness of its cause in several ways: *using the direct democratic tools in Switzerland to propose constitutional amendments and stimulate the public debate; *practical and legal information, such as alternatives to Switzerland's mandatory military service, e.g. [[Swiss Civilian Service]], often opted for by [[conscientious objectors]]; *media work, covering subjects such as arms equipment sales.
Currently, the group focuses on the following topics: *opposition to arms trade: In 2007, the group filed enough signatures for a national [[initiative]] against arms trade. The Swiss would vote in a referendum on an amendment to the constitution that would ban the export of any weapon from Switzerland. This national referendum was held on November 29, 2009. *opposition to arms procurements, for example against the fighter jets which the Swiss army is about to purchase; *constant criticism of Switzerland's militaristic traditions.
==Initiatives and referendums== In early 1986 the group launched its first [[popular initiative (Switzerland)|initiative]], named "Für eine Schweiz ohne Armee und für eine umfassende Friedenspolitik" (''For a Switzerland without an army and an overall peaceful political stance''), which gathered 111,300 signatures (100,000 were required to initiate a vote). On 26 November 1989, 68.6% of eligible voters cast their ballot, resulting in 1,052,218 (35.6%) votes for the initiative. The high percentage of yes voters stunned everybody,{{who|date=November 2010}} and was interpreted as a manifestation of a remarkable loss of significance of the military in Swiss society. Although the initiative was rejected, the surprising result of the initiative influenced later reforms of Switzerland's armed forces.
In Spring 1992, both chambers of the Swiss parliament decided to procure 34 [[F/A-18 Hornet]] fighter jets. Within 32 days, the GSoA gathered 503,719 signatures. Never before and never since has an initiative been submitted within such a short time or with a comparable number of signatures{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}}. Nevertheless, the Swiss people rejected the initiative on the ballot by 57% to 43%.
In 1999, the GSoA assisted in collecting the 50,000 valid signatures necessary for a referendum on whether Switzerland would join the [[United Nations]]. The Swiss electorate approved this proposal in 2002. In 2001, the GSoA gathered more than 60,000 signatures for a referendum against the revised legislation regulating the structure and deployment of the armed forces. The GSoA especially opposed the option to send armed troops abroad — a concern that was shared by some right-wing traditionalists. On 10 June 2001, the revised legislation was approved by 51% of the voters.
On 2 December 2001, Swiss voters considered two additional GSoA initiatives, called "In favor of a credible security policy and a Switzerland without an army" and "Solidarity instead of soldiers: In favor of a voluntary civilian peace service". In contrast to the first initiative to abolish the Swiss army, there was only sparse public debate on the issue - another topic dominated the media and the minds of the people: The [[September 11 attacks]] which occurred a few weeks before the vote took place. Both initiatives were rejected by 78% and 77% of the voters.
On 21 September 2007, the GSoA submitted an initiative that required a ban on all arms exports from Switzerland. This initiative was rejected on November 29, 2009 with 68.2% of the voters casting a no.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.admin.ch/ch/d/pore/vi/vis346.html |title=Eidgenössische Volksinitiative 'für ein Verbot von Kriegsmaterial-Exporten' |website=Admin.ch |date= |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref>
Another initiative required stricter legislation on private possession of firearms and a stop to the [[Gun politics in Switzerland|Swiss tradition]] to store the assault rifles of each soldier at home. The initiative was supported by some 40 organisations, of which the [[Social Democratic Party of Switzerland]], the [[Green Party of Switzerland]] and the GSoA made the largest contributions. The initiative was rejected on February 13, 2011 with 56.3% of the voters saying no.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110207040228/http://www.ejpd.admin.ch/content/ejpd/de/home/dokumentation/abstimmungen/2011-02-13.html ]</ref>
GSoA's initiative to abolish [[conscription]] was rejected by 73.2% of the Swiss electorate on September 22, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.admin.ch/ch/d/pore/vi/vis391.html |title=Eidgenössische Volksinitiative 'Ja zur Aufhebung der Wehrpflicht' |website=Admin.ch |date= |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref>
In 2008 the [[Swiss Federal Council]] announced its plans to purchase a new generation of fighter aircraft. Immediately after this, the GSoA started an initiative that proposes a 10-year-moratorium for aircraft procurements. The collection of signatures was completed in May 2009.<ref>''Swiss Face Fighter Vote'', ''[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]'', '''170''', 25 (22 June 2009), p. 12</ref> After garanting the group that there would be a Referendum about new fighter jets the group pulled the initiative back. When the parliament decided to buy new jets 2014 it was possible to collect signatures for a referendum which is easier to win than an initiative. In the end 53% of Swiss voters decided not to buy new [[Gripen]] fighter jets on May 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Geiser |first=Urs |url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/wings-of-air-force-clipped-in-nationwide-ballot/38606386 |title=Wings of air force clipped in nationwide ballot - SWI |website=Swissinfo.ch |date=2014-05-18 |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref> This was the first victory on the ballot for GSoA in a nationwide referendum.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *{{en icon}} {{Official website|http://www.gsoa.ch/gsoa/en/}}
{{Military of Switzerland}} {{Portal bar|Politics|War|Switzerland}}
