revision.text:
'''Reducing administrative burdens – effective inspection and enforcement''' (the '''Hampton Report''') is a March 2005 UK publication produced under businessman [[Philip Hampton]]. The UK Statutory Code of Practice for Regulators is based on its recommendations with the purpose to promote efficient and effective approaches to regulatory inspection and enforcement.<ref>[[BERR]] [http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file45019.pdf Statutory Code of Practice for Regulators], 17 December 2007</ref>
In the [[2004 Budget]], Hampton was asked to lead a review of regulatory inspection and enforcement. This review produced the ''Hampton Report''. This report, together with the later ''Macrory Review'' "Regulatory Justice – making sanctions effective"<ref>The Macrory Review is available @ http://www.bis.gov.uk/files/file44593.pdf</ref> led to the UK [[Regulatory Enforcement and Sanctions Act 2008]].<ref>The UK Regulatory Enforcement and Sanctions Act 2008 is available @ http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2008/13/pdfs/ukpga_20080013_en.pdf</ref>
One result was that the [[Ayres and Braithwaite Compliance Pyramid]] was effectively codified into UK law.
The Hampton Report also recommended an enhanced role for the [[Office of Fair Trading]] (OFT). The OFT were to set national priorities and coordinate performance management of local authority trading standards services. ==Local Better Regulation Office== The 2005 Report initiated the creation of the ''Local Better Regulation Office'' (LBRO) as a government-owned company [[statutory corporation]] with [[statutory powers]]. Previously the Consumer and Trading Standards Agency (CTSA), <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/bud_bud05_hampton.htm|title=Hampton review on regulatory inspections and enforcement|date=16 March 2005|accessdate=2009-01-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710064740/http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/bud_bud05_hampton.htm|archivedate=10 July 2009|df=}}</ref> it set out standards on how trading standards and other business regulators carried out their work to minimise the impact on legitimate business.
The LBRO was dissolved on 1 April 2012, its functions taken over by the [[Better Regulation Delivery Office]], an independent unit within the [[Department for Business, Innovation and Skills]].<ref>[http://www.lbro.org.uk/ LBRO website]</ref>
Dr. Clive Lester Grace, erstwhile Chair of the LBRO, was awarded an [[OBE]] in the [[2013 New Year Honours]] for services to Business and voluntary service to Communities.
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Economic history of the United Kingdom]]
{{UK-stub}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = In-Young Ahn | image = Dr. In-Young Ahn at the Korean Antarctic Station, King Sejong in October 2015.jpg | caption = Ahn at [[King Sejong Station]] | birth_name = | nationality = [[South Korea]]n | fields = Antarctic [[Benthic zone|Marine Ecology]] | workplaces = South Korean Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) | alma_mater = [[State University of New York at Stony Brook]] | known_for = First South Korean woman to visit Antarctica
First female Antarctic station leader from Asia | awards = | website = [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/In-Young_Ahn In-Young Ahn on ResearchGate] | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes | hangul = 안인영 | hanja = 安仁英{{cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=shm&sid1=104&oid=001&aid=0007173748|script-title=ja:南極科学基地の越冬隊長に初の女性任命|agency=Yonhap News Agency|date=2014-10-08|accessdate=2016-06-07}} | mr = An Inyŏng | rr = An Inyeong}} }} {{Eastern name order|Ahn In-Young}} '''In-Young Ahn''' is a South Korean scientist. She is known for being the first South Korean woman to visit [[Antarctica]] and the first Asian woman to become an [[Research stations in Antarctica|Antarctic station]] leader ([[King Sejong Station]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-05/women-scientists-in-antarctica-report-sexual-harassment/6443570|title=Stories of sexual harassment against women in Antarctica highlight issue in science industry|date=2015-05-04|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-06-03}}{{Cite web|url=https://womeninpolarsciencedotorg.files.wordpress.com/2015/12/womeninpolarscience-issueii.pdf|title=Newsletter Issue II|last=|first=|date=December 2015|website=womeninpolarscience.org|publisher=Women in Polar Science|access-date=2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2015/s4230123.htm|title=Southern Exposure|date=2015-05-05|website=ABC.com.au|access-date=2016-06-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/res/sites/news-projects/interactive-king-george-island/1.1.0/|title=King George Island's research stations|website=www.abc.net.au|publisher=ABC News|access-date=2016-06-30}} She is a [[Benthic zone|benthic]] ecologist and is currently working as a principal research scientist for Korea Polar Research Institute.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2015/s4230123.htm|title=Antarctica – Southern Exposure|website=abc.net.au|publisher=ABC|access-date=2016-06-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://eng.kopri.re.kr/www/about/kopri_brochure/annual_report_2015_eng.pdf|title=Annual Report|last=|first=|date=2015|website=eng.kopri.re.kr|publisher=Korea Polar Research Institute|access-date=2016}} ==Early life and education== Ahn graduated from [[Seoul National University]] in 1982 (majoring in Biological [[Oceanography]]) and then received her PhD in Coastal Oceanography from the [[State University of New York]] at [[Stony Brook University|Stony Brook]] in 1990. Ahn started her research at the Korean Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) on July 1, 1991. ==Career and impact== Ahn was in charge of [[environmental monitoring]] program at the King Sejong Station from 1996 to 2011, and conducted field surveys to obtain scientific data necessary for designation of the [[Antarctic Specially Protected Area]] (ASPA #171) near the Korean station. Ahn has also served as a representative and a National Contact Point of the Committee for Environmental Protection (CEP) at the [[Antarctic Treaty System|Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meetings]] from 1997 through 2014, until she was designated as the overwintering officer-in-charge.{{Cite web|url=http://eng.kopri.re.kr/home/contents/images/contents/e_5310000/Final_CEE_Jang_Bogo_ROK.pdf|title=Final Comprehensive Environmental Evaluation|last=|first=|date=April 2012|website=eng.kopri.re.kr|publisher=Korea Ppolar Research Institute|access-date=2016}} Ahn served as the vice president of the Korea Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) from May 2010 to June 2012. She also served as Vice President of the Korean Society of Oceanography in 2010–2011,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ksocean.or.kr/sub01_04.asp|title=연혁/역대회장|last=|first=|date=|website=ksocean.or.kr|publisher=Korean Society of Oceanography|language=ko|trans-title=History|access-date=}} and Korea Federation of Women's Science & Technology Associations in 2014 and 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kofwst.org/|title=한국여성과학기술단체총연합회|website=www.kofwst.org|publisher=|language=ko|trans-title=Korea Federation of Women's Science & Technology Associations|access-date=2016-06-03}} She was expedition leader of the 28th overwintering team (2015) of the South Korean King Sejong Antarctic station, where she served as the station chief for about a year. Ahn's research interests include Antarctic marine [[benthic zone|benthic ecology]] with special interests on benthic invertebrates and monitoring on Antarctic coastal marine ecosystems. She has studied the Antarctic clam ''[[Laternula elliptica]]'', a dominant marine [[Bivalvia|bivalve]] around Antarctic Continent. Ahn's current research includes studies on the impacts of [[Glacial motion|glacier retreat]] on nearshore marine benthic communities around the King Sejong Station. She is currently an adjunct professor at the [[Korea University of Science and Technology|University of Science & Technology]] (UST), and a principal research scientist at the Korean Polar Institute (KOPRI), which forms part of Korea Institute of Ocean Science & Technology (KIOST). ==Awards and honors== The South Korean government awarded Ahn a Medal of Science & Technology Merit for outstanding accomplishment in Antarctic Research in April 2001.{{Cite web|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=101&oid=001&aid=0000067080|title=과학기술진흥유공자 포상자 명단|date=2001|website=news.naver.com|publisher=yunhap news|trans-title=Science and Technology Merit list|access-date=2016-06-20}} She was further awarded a Commendation from the [[Ministry of Environment (South Korea)|South Korean Ministry of Environment]] in June 2008 for her contribution in the designation of Antarctic Specially Protected Area (ASPA #171) near the King Sejong station.{{Cite web|url=http://eng.kopri.re.kr/www/about/kopri_brochure/annual_report_2008.pdf|title=Annual Report|last=|first=|date=2008|website=kopri.re.kr|publisher=Korean Polar Research Institute|access-date=}} In 2016, she additionally received South Korea's [[Orders, decorations, and medals of South Korea|Prime Minister's award]] in recognition of her achievement as the station leader at King Sejong station.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ksg.co.kr/news/main_newsView.jsp?bbsID=news&bbsCategory=KSG&categoryCode=all&backUrl=main_news&pNum=108601|title=코리아쉬핑가제트|date=2016|work=Korea Shipping Gazette|trans-title=Golden Tower and Silver Tower Medals|access-date=2016-06-20}} ==Selected works== *Ahn, In-Young, et al. "First record of massive blooming of benthic diatoms and their association with megabenthic filter feeders on the shallow seafloor of an Antarctic fjord: Does glacier melting fuel the bloom?" ''Ocean Science Journal'' 51. 2 (2016): 273–279. *HW Moon, WMRW Hussin, HC Kim, In-Young Ahn*. "The Impacts of climate change on Antarctic nearshore mega-epifaunal benthic assemblages in a glacial fjord on King George Island: Responses and implications." ''Ecological Indicators'' 57 (2015): 280–292. *Ahn, In-Young, et al. "Influence of glacial runoff on baseline metal accumulation in the Antarctic limpet Nacella concinna from King George Island." ''Marine Pollution Bulletin'' 49 (2004): 119-141. *Ahn, In-Young, et al. "Growth and seasonal energetics of the Antarctic bivalve Laternula elliptica from King George Island, Antarctica." ''Marine Ecology Progress Series'' 257(2003): 99–110. *Ahn, In-Young, et al. "Baseline heavy metal concentrations in the Antarctic clam, Laternula elliptica in Maxwell Bay, King George Island, Antarctica." ''Marine Pollution Bulletin'' 32.8 (1996): 592–598. *Ahn, In-Young. "Enhanced particle flux through the biodeposition by the Antarctic suspension-feeding bivalve Laternula elliptica in Marian Cove, King George Island." ''Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology'' 171.1 (1993): 75–90. ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?user=HawzMpkAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=sra In-Young Ahn] on [[Google Scholar]] * [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/In-Young_Ahn In-Young Ahn] on [[ResearchGate]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahn, In-Young}} [[Category:South Korean women scientists]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:South Korean scientists]] [[Category:20th-century births]] [[Category:Women earth scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:20th-century South Korean scientists]] [[Category:21st-century South Korean scientists]]

revision.text:
'''InoForum''' — independent [[website|internet resource]], which searches for, translates and publishes in [[Russian language|Russian]] articles from foreign editions, first of all the ones that are political, related to [[Russia]] or the attitude towards Russia in various countries, as well as readers comments and forums. Translations are published daily.According to the information in the [http://www.inoforum.ru/spisok_publikacij archive of the site] (in Russian). Checked in September 2009. All the job to maintain the project is performed by volunteers from the readers of that internet resource. The job includes forming the contents (selection of articles, translating and editing), administration and technical support of the site. ==History== The independent internet project ''Inoforum'' was established on March 11, 2009 after [[Yaroslav Ognev]] left the [[Inosmi.Ru]] and a new editor-in-chief was assigned. It was planned, that ''Inosmi'' would broaden its informational and analytical activities, in particular, a feature of posting comments to articles would be introduced, while the comments would become a source of opinions and contents for the foreign editions. While the forum of ''Inosmi'' known in the [[Runet]] for its speech freedom and patriotically minded visitors would cease its existence, as many forum visitors were concerned.[http://www.nestor.minsk.by/kg/news/2009/03/2101.html Cyberpartisans from Inoforum declared a war against Inosmi], by Pavel Brel (in Russian) {{cquote| Today media resources get more and more interested in what's called ''user generated content''... I would like the InoSmi readers to be those ''opinion makers'' that I would manage to ''trade'' in ''exchange'' for the content legalization.[http://www.rian.ru/news_company/20090311/164475711.html Marina Pustilnik is assigned Editor-in-Chief of InoSmi], by [[RIAN]], March 11, 2009 (in Russian)

'''[[Marina Pustilnik]]''' }} A lot of ''Inosmi'' readers and forum participants did not support changes to the politics of the resource.[http://journalisti.ru/?p=2309 Inosmi? No, Inoforum!], Journalisti.Ru (in Russian) In their blogs and personal websites forum participants of ''Inosmi'' openly expressed their discontent with the ongoing events and took a series of actions to preserve the format of the site and of discussions they were accustomed to. First of all, ''Inosmi'' fans were assured [http://www.rusk.ru/newsdata.php?idar=181900 Liberal revenge], by Rusk.Ru (in Russian) that the site would cease to be the independent information source about Russia. Reminding the great role that it played in covering the [[2008 South Ossetian war]] and bringing the facts to the western readers, ''Inosmi'' fans clarified their position in the "Open letter of Inosmi forum participants": {{cquote|We believe, that the new politics will not only cause the death of a powerful means of patriotic upbringing of a great amount of literate, educated, socially active citizens of Russia, but will also lead to establishment of the resource engaged in the dangerous, corrupting activity...}} ''Inoforum'' is the specialized site of free discussing of foreign press articles, commentaries of foreign readers and forums in foreign languages. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://inoforum.ru/ Inoforum] {{DEFAULTSORT:Inoforum}} [[Category:Russian news websites]] {{Russia-stub}}

{{Infobox football tournament | name = Mascom Top 8 Cup | logo = | country = {{BOT}} | founded = 2012 | number of teams = 8 | current champions = [[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]] (2017–18) | most successful club = [[Gaborone United S.C.|Gaborone United]]
[[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]]
(2 titles) | website = | current = [[2017–18 Mascom Top 8 Cup]] }} The '''Mascom Top 8 Cup''' is a [[Association football|football]] cup competition in [[Botswana]]. It was created in 2012, and features the top eight finishers from the [[Botswana Premier League]].[http://www.premierleague.co.bw/mascom.php BPL Mascom Top 8 Cup] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224121716/http://www.premierleague.co.bw/mascom.php |date=2014-02-24 }}, Botswana Premier League[http://www.premierleague.co.bw/docs/mascomtop8.pdf Mascom Top 8 Tournament Rules and Regulations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224123753/http://www.premierleague.co.bw/docs/mascomtop8.pdf |date=2014-02-24 }}, Botswana Premier League[http://www.dailynews.gov.bw/news-details.php?nid=6730 Clash of titans as Mascom Top 8 gets underway], Botswana Daily News Since 2013, the winners qualify for the [[CAF Confederation Cup]], as the [[FA Challenge Cup (Botswana)|FA Challenge Cup]] is not played. ==List of finals== *2011/12: [[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]] 3-1 [[ECCO City Green]]s[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bots2012.html#cups Botswana 2011/12], RSSSF.com[http://www.rollersfc.com/sample-page-2/rollers-wins-mascom-top8/ Rollers wins Mascom Top8], Township Rollers[http://www.biztechafrica.com/article/township-rollers-bag-mascom-top-8/3716/#.UuYHbRCmrIU Township Rollers bag Mascom Top 8], BizTechAfrica *2012/13: [[Gaborone United S.C.|Gaborone United]] 2-1 [[Botswana Defence Force XI FC|Botswana Defence Force]][http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bots2013.html#cups Botswana 2012/13], RSSSF.com[http://www.gaboroneunited.co.bw/index.php?supa=dikgang&id=593 THE REDS CROWNED MASCOM TOP 8 CHAMPIONS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203161806/http://www.gaboroneunited.co.bw/index.php?supa=dikgang&id=593 |date=2014-02-03 }}, Gaborone United[http://www.dailynews.gov.bw/news-details.php?nid=2862 Gaborone United walk away with P1m], Botswana Daily News *2013/14: [[Botswana Defence Force XI F.C.|Botswana Defence Force XI]] 1-1 (aet; 5-4 pen.) [[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]][http://www.dailynews.gov.bw/news-details.php?nid=9285 BDF XI are champs], Botswana Daily News *2014/15: [[Gaborone United S.C.|Gaborone United]] 2-1 [[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]][http://botswanapremierleague.com/news/525848/Gaborone-United-win-Mascom-top-8 Gaborone United win Mascom top 8] *2015/16: [[Orapa United F.C.|Orapa United]] 3-1 (aet) [[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]][http://botswanapremierleague.com/news/626145/Orapa-stun-Rollers-to-lift-Mascom-Top-8-Cup Orapa stun Rollers to lift Mascom Top 8 Cup] *2016/17: [[Jwaneng Galaxy F.C.|Jwaneng Galaxy]] 4-3 (aet) [[Orapa United F.C.|Orapa United]][http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?aid=67889&dir=2017/april/03 Sesinyi-Inspired Galaxy Sweep Ostriches] *2017/18: [[Township Rollers F.C.|Township Rollers]] 4-2 [[Orapa United F.C.|Orapa United]][https://botswanapremierleague.com/news/743856/Township-Rollers-claim-Mascom-Top-8-glory Township Rollers claim Mascom Top 8 glory] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140308070354/http://www.premierleague.co.bw/cups.php Official webpage of BPL Mascom Top 8 Cup], Botswana Premier League *[http://botswanapremierleague.com/tournament/254/2014-15-Mascom-Top-8 2014/15 Mascom Top 8], Botswana Premier League {{Football in Botswana}} [[Category:Football competitions in Botswana]] {{Botswana-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=April 2008}} [[File:Mediengruppe Telekommander-2006-06-25.jpg|right|thumb|Mediengruppe Telekommander performing live at the [http://www.donauinselfest.at Donauinselfest 2006] festival on the [[Donauinsel|Danube Island]] in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] on June 25th, 2006.]]
'''Mediengruppe Telekommander''', founded in 2001 by Florian Zwietnig and Gerald Mandl, was an [[Austria]]n/[[Germany|German]] electronic band. Since 2002, they have gained considerable attention in the media of [[Germany]] and Austria.
The band depicts and criticizes today's consumerist culture with harsh lyrics and their distinctive fusion of indie/punk rock, hip hop, and electronic music.
The duo disbanded shortly after the release of their last single in 2011.
== Discography ==
* EP 1 (vinyl single 2002) * EP 2 (vinyl single 2003) * ''Trend'' (single 2004) * ''Die ganze Kraft einer Kultur'' (2004) * ''Bis zum Erbrechen schreien'' (single 2004) * ''Sprengkörper'' (12" club single 2006) * ''Näher am Menschen'' (2006) * ''Endlosrille'' (single 2009) * ''Einer muss in Führung gehen'' (single 2009) * ''Einer muss in Führung gehen'' (2009) * ''Deine Schule (Single)'' (2011) * ''Die Elite der Nächstenliebe'' (Album) (2011) * ''Billig (Single)'' (2011)
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040608144049/http://www.mediengruppetelekommander.de/ Official website (in German)]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Austrian musical groups]]
{{europe-band-stub}}

page.title: Run Away (SunStroke Project and Olia Tira song)

revision.text:
{{Infobox single | Name = Run Away | Cover = Olia_Tira_Sunstroke_Project.jpg | Border = yes | Artist = [[SunStroke Project]] and [[Olia Tira]] | Released = 2010 | Format = [[Digital single]], [[CD single]] | Recorded = 2010 | Genre = {{hlist|[[Dance-pop]]|[[Eurodance]]|[[Europop]]}} | Length = 2:58 | Label = | Writer = {{hlist|Anton Ragoza|[[Sergey Stepanov (musician)|Sergey Stepanov]]|Alina Galetskaya}} | Producer = | Chronology = [[SunStroke Project]] singles | Last single = "Summer"
(2009) | This single = "'''Run Away'''"
(2010) | Next single = "Play with Me"
(2010) | Misc = {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{Flag icon|Moldova}} "Run Away" | image = | caption = | year = 2010 | country = Moldova | artist = [[SunStroke Project]] and [[Olia Tira]] | as = | with = | language = English | composer = Anton Ragoza, [[Sergey Stepanov (musician)|Sergey Stepanov]] | lyricist = Alina Galetskaya | place = 22nd | points = 27 | place_semi = 10th | points_semi = 52 | lyrics = | prev = Hora din Moldova | prev_link = Hora din Moldova | next = So Lucky | next_link = So Lucky (Zdob şi Zdub song) }}}} "'''Run Away'''" is a song performed by [[SunStroke Project]] and [[Olia Tira]], and represented [[Moldova]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]] in May 2010 in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. The song won the final of the ''[[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2010|O melodie pentru Europa 2010]]'', that took place on 6 March. It gained the maximum number of points from both the juries and the televotes.{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=10103&_t=Sun+Stroke+Project+%26+Olia+Tira+for+Moldova!|title=Sun Stroke Project & Olia Tira for Moldova!|last=Brey|first=Marco|date=6 March 2010|publisher=''[[European Broadcasting Union]]''|accessdate=6 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201213753/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=10103&_t=Sun+Stroke+Project+%26+Olia+Tira+for+Moldova! |archivedate=2014-02-01 |deadurl=no}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/15314|title=Moldova sends Sunstroke Project & Olia Tira to Eurovision|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=6 March 2010|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=6 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229075036/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/15314 |archivedate=2012-02-29 |deadurl=no}} In the contest, it was performed first on the night of the first semi-final, preceding Russia's [[Lost and Forgotten]] and passed to the final. The inspiration for the "Epic Jazz Jive" came from observing ducks, waddling through sand, on the beach. After the contest, "Run Away" would also become the subject of a major [[internet meme]] surrounding the [[saxophone]] solos performed by saxophonist [[Sergey Stepanov (musician)|Sergey Stepanov]] who, in a phenomenon similar to [[Rickrolling]] and [[Eduard Khil|Trololo]], was dubbed the "'''Epic Sax Guy'''" in videos on [[YouTube]].{{cite web|title=Epic Sax Guy (The One)|url=http://www.urlesque.com/2010/07/29/epic-sax-guy/|work=URLesque|publisher=Aol|accessdate=8 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202115725/http://www.urlesque.com/2010/07/29/epic-sax-guy/ |archivedate=2014-02-02 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |title= Is this guy the Web's new rickroll? |first= Damon |last= Brown |url= http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/web/08/02/damon.brown.epic.sax.guy/ |newspaper=CNN |date= 2 August 2010 |accessdate= 31 May 2014 |page= |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100814174722/http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/web/08/02/damon.brown.epic.sax.guy/ |archivedate=2010-08-14 |deadurl=no}} Later, this song is used more as background music of video gaming(such as ''[[Hearthstone]]'' and ''[[Rainbow Six Siege]]'')"Best moments" videos.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} The [[Rules of the Eurovision Song Contest|rules of the contest]] prohibited musical instruments being played on stage, meaning Stepanov was not actually playing the saxophone at all, but rather synchronising movements with a prerecorded track. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2010) ! scope="col"| Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Norway|7|artist=SunStroke Project & Olia Tira|song=Run Away|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|Sweden|31|artist=SunStroke Project & Olia Tira|song=Run Away|rowheader=true}} |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ECyeUYsU14E Official music video] – YouTube * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kxopViU98Xo 10 hours of Epic Sax Guy] {{Eurovision Song Contest 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Run Away (Sunstroke Project And Olia Tira Song)}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2010]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Moldova]] [[Category:2010 singles]] [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:2010 songs]] {{Moldova-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=March 2013}} The '''Slovak diaspora''' refers to both historical and present [[emigration]] from [[Slovakia]], as well as from the former [[Czechoslovakia]]. The country with the largest number of [[Slovaks]] living abroad is the [[United States]].
==Famous people of Slovak descent== {{maincat|People of Slovak descent}} [[File:Congressman Sestak Official Congressional headshot.jpg|thumb|[[Joe Sestak]], a former U.S. Navy three-star Admiral and former American politician]] [[File:Angelina Jolie 2 June 2014 (cropped).jpg|thumb|[[Angelina Jolie]], an American actress and film director]]
* [[Enki Bilal]], a French comic book creator, comics artist and film director. * [[David Boreanaz]], an American actor, television producer, and director. * [[Jon Voight]], an American actor * [[Eugene Cernan]], a retired United States Navy officer and a former NASA astronaut. * [[Renée Geyer]], an Australian singer who has long been regarded as one of the finest exponents of jazz, soul and R&B idioms. * [[Lukáš Hrádecký]], a Slovak-born Finnish football goalkeeper. * [[Tim Hudak]], a politician in Ontario, Canada, and the Leader of the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario (PC Party). * [[Angelina Jolie]], an American actress and film director. * [[Jon Bon Jovi]], an American musician, singer, songwriter, record producer and actor. * [[Jim Caviezel]], an American actor. * [[Mike Cervenak]], an American baseball player. * [[Ricardo de Jaxa Malachowski]], a Peruvian architect of Polish and Slovak origin. * [[Stan Mikita]], a Slovak-born Canadian retired professional ice hockey player. * [[Paul Newman]], an American actor, film director, entrepreneur, humanitarian, and professional racing driver. * [[Andrew Poje]], a Canadian ice dancer. * [[Ivan Reitman]], film director * [[Jason Reitman]], film director * [[François Sagat]], a French male pornographic actor, model and director. * [[Angel Dark]], a Slovakian adult film star * [[Joe Sestak]], a former U.S. Navy three-star Admiral and former American politician. * [[Jesse Ventura]], an American politician, actor, author, veteran, and former professional wrestler. * [[Andy Warhol]], an American artist who was a leading figure in the visual art movement known as pop art.
{{clear}}
